data.title: Nearly broke my tooth.
data.text: Stopped in after a show on third street to order a couple of sammies. Although they tasted good; the cheese & avocadoes were fresh, I bit down onto something sooooooooooo hard it hurt! We were already @ home so I spit out this lil black ball the size of a pea & put it in a lil baggie. I went back there the next day to inform them of just what I'd found. I waited my turn & then told the owner/attendant what happened. She looked @ it and told me it was an avocado end pit and so "WHAT DID I WANT?" in a very snotty voice. I was stunned! I didn't want anything! I wanted to save the next person from this horrible experience & for them just to be more careful in the future. Most of the clientele sitting there were over 50 & I could only imagine what if one of them broke a tooth & had no insurance? Plus it was hurtful in two different ways. No I will not be back. So not worth it.

data.title: Surprise!  Its Oosterwyk's Dutch Bakery Inc.
data.text:
Well, whoever submitted this first time mis-spelled the name and got the business title incorrect.....Yet, it is what it is---a family run bakery in the Dutch tradition that serves soup, sandwiches, offering teas and coffees to go with your choice of many cookies, bars, danishes, pecan-rolls, twists, long-johns, bismarks, fresh baked loaves of  bread, and where you can order cakes....eat in or take out--

-personal past observations aside as to staff attitude "observed" not to be seen during our visit---in fact, one patron who ordered a cookie $1.20 complained that there was a service charge added for use of  the credit/debit card---staff was very kind...the patron less so--one wonders today what "business folk" haven't got at least $2 in their pocket---

Most folks today have no clue how much the banks charge merchants so that
the convenience of the card is available---passed on in either product costs
or service charges---- Banker Executives don't care about you---Do your merchant a favor----use CASH! for these kinds of purchases. Small businesses will appreciate both your purchases and your patronage consideration using cash---What a great place to sit, enjoy your favorite drink and a cookie.Parking free street-side.

They import genuine Stroopwafflen....and other Dutch treats.

data.title: Yummm!
data.text: This place has really good bakery items.  I know a lot of people who   love it.  The one time I went for lunch, I thought one of the women was rude, but that just seemed like her personality.  (a la Soup Nazi)

data.title: Go early and the "surprise" pkgs for $2 are amazing
data.text: Although somewhat limited with bread choices, the case of choices is profound and pretty divine. At Christmas the line is long and one may find themselves ordering more than necessary or reasonable when your turn comes.

data.title: Good place for lunch and bakery goods
data.text: We eat sandwich and soup lunches here half-dozen times a year.  Food is always good.  Bakery has lots of goodies to eat on site or take home.  Charges extra for using a credit card though.

data.title: Dutch Bakery
data.text:
Excellent bakery. Many different pastries and seasonal baked goods. Also a very good lunch.
I believe it's a family owned business.

data.title: Great little gem
data.text: This is a great little gem in our town.  It's worth going just for the bakery smell but the food is good too.  Worth the stop for sure

data.title: Love this bakery
data.text: My family and I go here all the time and love it. My fathers favorites are  the breads and I love the almond cookies. I also really like the Dutch decorations. The lighting is not the best but we like to sit in the front near the window. I plan on getting my wedding cake done here when I get married hopefully they are still around.

data.title: Excellend baked goods
data.text: This is a Dutch bakery, and they have the typical danish and donuts in addition to some Dutch specialties.  I highly recommend the Dutch almond cookies with the soft center (whatever they are called), and the danish.  The coffee cakes are very good as well.  I've never bothered trying much else here, but what I've had has been excellent.  Prices are very reasonable as well.  There is some seating if you want to sit and have a cup of coffee with your bakery items, but it really is more of an old traditional bakery.  I'm a baked goods snob and this place is right up there with any of the newer fancy bakeries in Seattle or Bellingham.  They are closed Sunday and Monday.

data.title: Extremely substandard, miserable customer service
data.text:
Pros:  Location, right on main street
Cons:  Extremely substandard, miserable customer service.

We visited Oosterwyk's Dutch Bakery at 115 3rd Street in Marysville, Washington on July 20, 2013.  They had a very limited variety of baked goods at our time of visit (around 11:30 in the morning) including turnovers, cookies, and orange bread to eat in or take out.

The bakery is located in the "historic" section of Marysville.  Upon entering, the decor was very dated and it was dark inside.  The display cases with the baked goods were smudged with fingerprints.  There were crumbs on the floor.

We entered the bakery and got in line behind a family who was completing a to go order.  The family asked for a bag and a woman with behind the counter, handed them a plastic bag.  The family asked if they could get another bag so the beignets they purchased would not get smashed, but the woman refused to give them more than one bag and insisted they just set the beignets on top.

As we stepped forward, the woman glared at my daughter who had her cell phone in her hand (she was not on it, just holding it) as we noticed a "no cell phone" sign.

When we ordered our items (two apple turnovers and a chocolate croissant), my husband pulled out a $50 bill to pay with and the woman said, "I don't have change for a fifty." I looked at the open cash register where another lady behind the counter was making change for a $20 bill and it saw it was overflowing with bills of many denominations. The woman saw me look at the register and she shut the drawer on abruptly on the other woman. The other lady said something about it and the woman said, "it was poking me in the back."

My husband looked in his wallet for a smaller bill while we asked for a milk or chocolate milk for my daughter. She curtly said, "I have no milk." My husband then asked for a Diet Coke for himself, and the woman walked over to the cooler and pulled out a Diet Coke, then announced to us, "I have small chocolate milks, do you want one of those?"  I looked at my daughter to see if she still wanted the milk and the woman impatiently said, "Do you want one?"  We replied, "yes," and she grabbed one and set it down hard on the counter.

At this point, my husband decided enough was enough.  He said, "Forget it, I'd rather not have to deal with this horrible woman," and turned to go out the door.  I added, "we didn't have a smaller bill anyway," while the woman glared as I turned and she began saying something inaudible as we left.

If you feel that quality customer service is an important part of your dining experience, then do not eat at Oosterwyk's Dutch Bakery.  I am unable to vouch for their baked goods as our family decided not to support the rudeness we endured by purchasing any of their food.

The woman at Oosterwyk's Dutch Bakery could use some help in people skills and customer service.  I believe eating out should be an enjoyable experience that encompasses not only our taste buds, but our other feelings as well.  Customers do not appreciate being treated as if they are a burden, but want to feel welcome in the restaurant.
